prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mapping CO(1-0) and 3mm continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal is to map 3mm continuum to image the free-free structure of the HII region while at the same time to get simultaneous CO(1-0) detection. The 3mm continuum will be used to subtract the free-free from the 870 micron continuum to get the spatial distribution of the dust continuum. The total flux is about 40 mJy but that is for the entire source; we expect to resolve that and image structure, hence the requested sensitivity.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our main goal at 3mm is to image continuum, although we would also like to image CO(1-0), which is currently undetected.
The expected total continuum flux is about 40 mJy, but we will be resolving this so the fluxes per synthesized beam will be lower, 0.2 mJy or less. We base our sensitivities on the 7mm VLA image of Turner and Beck 2004 in which faint features around the HII region core are seen down to the rms of 110microJy; the ALMA map will improve on this rms by factor 3. The OT gives sensitivity of 32 microJy over the entire bandwidth. We request the maximum spatial resolution of 0.28" to most closely match the high resolution at 870microns to resolve the HII region on cluster scales.
The high spatial resolution 3mm continuum image will be used for determining the free-free contribution to the submm emission, which will be used to correct the 870micron flux for the free-free component to get the spatial distribution of the dust emission. High sensitivity is required to be able to do this at the requested spatial resolution.
We include the CO(1-0) line, which will be weaker than CO(3-2) of Science Goal 2. If necessary we can smooth over the line to improve the image. We estimate the CO(1-0) flux based on thin emission from our SMA CO(3-2) image, if this emission is spread over the ~2" size estimated from that image.

This science goal is continuum-driven, so there are three bands of continuum and all are needed to get the requested sensitivity to continuum.
We have included the CO(1-0) line, which has not yet been detected and will give an interesting Xco value. We spectral average by 2 but this line is not broad, 9km/s in CO(3-2), so we can't do more.

We want to image Cloud D to see the inner shell created by the embedded HII region. SMA images show that Cloud D is about 1-2" across, which is about 25-30 pc. We want to image on the scale of the embedded cluster, which is likely to be 3 pc across judging from the sizes of Galactic globular clusters. 0.25" is ~4 pc. (Actually we can't quite do .25" but the OT accepts .28". 0.3" would also be OK.)
SMA images have the size of Cloud D at less than 4". There might be extensions along one axis, but this is about the largest scale. We do not need the compact array.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mapping CO3-2 and 870micron continuum in NGC 5253
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mapping the CO(3-2) and 870 micron continuum in NGC5253. CO(3-2) is used to map the warm gas. CO(3-2) is chosen because the emission detected toward Cloud D is optically thin and the cloud is very warm. 870 micron continuum is key for determining dust masses, in conjunction with the 3mm map, since the 3mm traces free-free emission, which is a sizeable contribution to the submm continuum flux (Turner et al. 2015). The 870 micron continuum will be a mixture of dust and free-free.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We request the maximum possible resolution to resolve the shell within Cloud D containing the super star cluster, since 0.25" ~ 4 pc, about the size of the cluster itself. This will allow us to map out the shell created by the embedded cluster. Spectral resolution is based on the linewidth of Cloud D, which is 9 km/s. We aim to image structures of ~1K at the full spectral and spatial resolution, but we can always smooth in space or frequency to improve signal to noise if needed for the line observations.
The sensitivity request is based on the observed 1.9Jy peak in SMA channel maps of Turner et al. 2015, assuming that the emission is spread over the 2" estimated source size. This gives 30mJy in a .25" synthesized beam. Hence we request 2.5mJy sensitivity in the line. It appears to be somewhat more confined, so we should have better S/N.
The other consideration is continuum, since determining the distribution of dust is also a key science goal. This actually drives the sensitivity, to match the 3mm free-free continuum sensitivity, which is determined by the free-free fluxes, although it is consistent with the needs for CO(3-2).
870micron continuum observations will be used to produce better models to estimate dust mass, a central goal of the proposal since our low resolution SMA image suggests a dust excess. We will use 3mm continuum to subtract free-free emission, which is significant here (Hirashita 2013, Turner et al. 2015). This needs to be done spatially, since to obtain a good dust temperature estimate using DUSTY we need an inner and outer dust shell radius. The dust contribution is about equal to the free-free, so our continuum sensitivity for this science goal of .04 mJy driven by the line observations matches well with the Goal 1 requested sensitivity for the 3mm continuum map of 0.3, when added to the continuum that we get from Science Goal 3. This sensitivity will allow us to do the free-free subtraction.

For CO(3-2) we need to have good resolution on a line that is 9 km/s wide. We have 2 km/s to calculate sensitivity. We can smooth but given the narrowness of the line and the fact that we will resolve the cloud and hopefully its kinematic structure we use this value.

The maximum angular resolution is chosen to be 0.25" to image Cloud D on scales that will resolve the cluster, about 4pc at the distance of NGC 5253. This is important for determining both the distribution of gas through CO(3-2) but also the distribution of free-free emission and dust emission.
One of our primary questions is why does Cloud D seem so undisturbed by this massive cluster; the free-free and molecular gas comparison can help link the two. The other question is what is the source of the submm excess, is it dust production by the cluster. Thus it is important to image the dust at matching resolution and see how well mixed the dust is with the gas. We're guessing it is more concentrated, since it is coming from the stars.
As far as the largest angular scale goes, the SMA has shown that it is <4" for the GMC and the HII region should be smaller. So this is not an extended source and does not need the compact array.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 870micron continuum and H26alpha
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The H26alpha line should be bright in the supernebula by ALMA standards, with a peak flux of about 45mJy by our estimation (Scoville & Murchikova 2013), so it can be mapped. H26a is very important for getting a linewidth, to constrain the stellar mass embedded in this nebula and otherwise to study the gas kinematics of the HII region for comparison with models.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We need a good linewidth for the H26alpha for the goal of getting a dynamical mass for the embedded cluster. The line is expected to be ~50-60km/s, FWHM, over the source although this is integrated over the source so it might be smaller when spatially resolved. We use therefore the 0.8 km/s setup for the correlator, spectral average 8, although we base our sensitivity calculations on 7km/s, which adequately Nyquist samples the line (thermal width ~20 km/s FWHM) for centroid determinations.

We need the highest resolution we can to resolve this super star cluster and its HII region and its GMC. The HII region will be smaller than the CO(3-2) shell of Goal 2, and may not be resolved at this resolution. At 3.8Mpc, 1" =18 pc, this gives about 4pc per beam. The core of the HII region is smaller than this as suggested by VLA 7mm observations, but we can resolve the north south arcs and wings present in the VLA image, and potentially also the gradient indicated by the H53alpha images with the VLA at lower (3") resolution (Rodriguez-Rico et al. 2007).
This source is smaller than 4". Compact array not needed.

The H26alpha line flux is expected to have a peak flux of 44 mJy, based on the well-known Lyman continuum rate for this nebula, using the analysis of Scoville & Murchikova 2013. If we map this it will be about 3-4 mJy/beam based on VLA images. We're using 7 km/s for the sensitivity calculation (next paragraph) but in reality the thermal linewidth for H is ~20km/s so the S/N will be a factor of 2 higher than the OT is getting.
We also need a good linewidth for our science goals, and also determining a potential faint blue wings for weaker freatures. We estimate that we need ~1-1.5 mJy in a 7 km/s channel to get faint blue wings if we integrate spatially over the source, based on [SIV] profiles (Beck et al. 2013) and to Nyquist sample the thermal linewidth, which is ~20km/s FWHM (the overall linewidth is broader because of gravitational broadening). This is important for measuring line centroids. We will use the linewidth plus extent of the H26alpha to obtain an estimate of the stellar mass (or at least a good upper limit) of the cluster and this should give sufficient sensitivity to also get a good overall linewidth. This is important because the nebula is gravity-bound. We can also use the continuum to add to the continuum of Goal 2 to improve S/N in the 870 micron continuum map of dust plus free-free.
To get a better spatial distribution of H26alpha, we will improve over this basic sensitivity by spectrally smoothing over the 60 km/s line. This should agree with the free-free map.
The other consideration is continuum sensitivity. As discussed in Science Goal 2 we need to subtract the 3mm free-free from the 870micron continuum to get the dust distribution; the detailed map of dust is an important science goal. We will combine the continua from these two Science Goals to get an 870micron continuum map with sensitivity as close as possible to the 3mm continuum. The free-free and dust separately are also about 40mJy spread over the source but this gets down to about 100-200 microJy when mapped.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe the giant molecular cloud, Cloud D, and the supernebula associated with a forming super star cluster in NGC 5253 in CO(3-2), CO(1-0), H26 alpha, 2.6mm and 870micron continuum at 0.25 arcseconds resolution, to examine the molecular cloud-HII region-cluster interaction on parsec scales.
